Summary

A review of Bryan A. Garner's "A Dictionary of Modern American Usage." Wallace applies George Orwell's Politics and the English Language to grammar and the conditions of class and power in millennial American communication. In addition to examining seemingly technical ideas such as descriptive linguistics versus prescriptive grammar, Wallace digresses to discuss the legitimacy of Ebonics as opposed to "white male" standard English.

Themes

The Democratic Spirit

Wallace defines the Democratic Spirit as "one that combines rigor and humility, i.e., passionate conviction plus a sedulous respect for the convictions of others." He adds that maintaining the Democratic Spirit "so hard to maintain on certain issues that it's almost irresistibly tempting to fall in with some established dogmatic camp" (72). Wallace submits that one of the reasons Garner is a genius is that he honors the D.S. by "considering the reader's own hopes and fears and reasons for caring enough about usage to bother with something like ADMAU at all" (124).

Wallace argues that the language used now a days, known as Standard Written English, can also be called Standard White English. He gives the reader an example of a lecture where he acknowledges its existence and might appear to be acceptant of it. But he argues that his "humble opinion is that some of the cultural and political realities of American life are themselves racially insensitive and elitist and offensive and unfair, and that pussyfooting around these realities with euphemistic doublespeak is not only hypocritical but toxic to the project of ever really changing them" (109). Hence, his argument is that in order to change the connotations of language and make it more "democratic," there first has to be an acceptance that such a problem exists in order for it to be fixed.

Wallace also introduces the term "SNOOT", which is a term derived form an acronym (possibly standing for "Syntax Nudniks Of Our Time") and meant to refer to a Grammar Nazi or Usage Nerd, etc.. Wallace is a self-proclaimed SNOOT, though he in this essay certainly mixes his SNOOTiness with generous measures of the aforementioned Democratic Spirit.

Alternative Theme Analysis

Wallace's view is flawed in that he assumes there is a racial identity to a language.

This is only true if somehow magically only one group of people could speak a certain language, and others, no matter how hard they tried, could not learn that language.

But this is not true: anyone can learn any language, regardless of their “race.” It just takes practice.

In this sense, language is not a genetic factor but comes about as a result of people needing to communicate with others within their geographical range.

So when Wallace and others posit that there is a “Black English,” they are indeed being narrow-minded, and a little racist (this is a perspective taken up by Kweisi Mfume (former president of the NAACP), Jesse Jackson, and myself).

This position is based on the logic that “Black English” is not a result of genetics, but of a geographical dialect of what’s considered Standard English, and is not exclusive to Black people (see rapper Eminem, who is considered White by many but speaks in Black English in his music).

Though Wallace is on to something in saying that a Standard English is spoken, and one must know how to speak that English if one expects to succeed within a system depending upon SWE to function – in theory it would not matter which dialect is the Standard, there would always need to be a standard for anything to get done (I realize this statement itself is another can of worms, though I enter it as a topic worth further debate).

Reference(s):

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African_American_Vernacular_English

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eminem

Voice

Wallace gives us his reaction to what Authority is and how it pertains to American usage, labeling himself with the proud label of a SNOOT.

Context

The essay was originally published in the April 2001 issue of Harper's Magazine as "Tense Present: Democracy, English, and the Wars Over Usage."
